titleStmt.title: Some q-rung orthopair fuzzy maclaurin symmetric mean operators and their applications to potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization

affiliation.orgName: Yunnan University of Finance and Economics
Yunnan University of Finance and Economics
Construction Plan of Scientific Research Innovation Team for Colleges and Universities in Sichuan Province

analytic.title: Some q-rung orthopair fuzzy maclaurin symmetric mean operators and their applications to potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The Maclaurin symmetric mean (MSM) operator is a classical mean type aggregation operator used in modern information fusion theory, which is suitable to aggregate numerical values. The prominent characteristic of the MSM operator is that it can capture the interrelationship among the multi-input arguments. In this paper, we extend the MSM operator and dual MSM operator to q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets to propose the q-rung orthopair fuzzy MSM operator, q-rung orthopair fuzzy dual MSM operator, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted MSM operator, and q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted dual MSM operator. Then, some desirable properties and special cases of these operators are discussed in detail. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the feasibility of the proposed methods and deliver the sensitivity analysis and comparative analysis.

dual Maclaurin symmetric mean (DMSM) operator, emerging technology commercialization, Maclaurin symmetric mean (MSM) operator, multiple attribute decision making (MADM), potential evaluation, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted dual MSM (q-ROFWDMSM) operator, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted MSM (q-ROFWMSM) operator

div.head: | INTRODUCTION
div.p: Atanassov 1,2 introduced the concept of an intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS), which is a generalization of the concept of a fuzzy set. 3 Each element in the IFS is expressed by an ordered pair, and each ordered

pair is characterized by a membership degree and a nonmembership degree. The sum of the membership degree and the nonmembership degree of each ordered pair is less than or equal to 1. The IFS has received more and more attention since its appearance. More recently, Pythagorean fuzzy set (PFS) 25,26 has emerged as an effective tool for depicting uncertainty of the multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problems. The PFS is also characterized by the membership degree and the nonmembership degree, whose sum of squares is less than or equal to 1, the PFS is more general than the IFS. In some cases, the PFS can solve the problems that the IFS cannot, for example, if a DM gives the membership degree and the nonmembership degree as 0.8 and 0.6, respectively, then it is only valid for the PFS. In other words, all the intuitionistic fuzzy degrees are a part of the Pythagorean fuzzy degrees, which indicates that the PFS is more powerful to handle the uncertain problems. Zhang and Xu 27 provided the detailed mathematical expression for PFS and introduced the concept of Pythagorean fuzzy number (PFN). Meanwhile, they also developed a Pythagorean fuzzy technique for order preference by similarity to an ideal solution for handling the MCDM problem within PFNs. Peng and Yang 28 proposed the division and subtraction operations for PFNs, and also developed a Pythagorean fuzzy superiority and inferiority ranking method to solve the multicriteria group decision-making problem with PFNs. Afterward, Beliakov and James 29 focused on how the notion of "averaging" should be treated in the case of PFNs and how to ensure that the averaging aggregation functions produce outputs consistent with the case of ordinary fuzzy numbers. Reformat and Yager 30 applied the PFNs in handling the collaborative-based recommender system. Gou et al 31 investigated the properties of continuous PFN. Ren et al 32 proposed the Pythagorean fuzzy TODIM approach to multicriteria decision making. Garg 33 proposed the new generalized Pythagorean fuzzy information aggregation by using Einstein operations. Zeng et al 34 developed a hybrid method for Pythagorean fuzzy multiple-criteria decision making. Wu and Wei 35 used Hamacher operations [36][37][38][39][40] to develop some Pythagorean fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators. Ren et al 41 developed the Pythagorean fuzzy TODIM approach, which is useful to cope with the MCDM problems that consider the DMs' psychological behaviors in an uncertain circumstance. Zeng et al 42 developed a hybrid method for Pythagorean fuzzy multiple-criteria decision making. Wei and Lu 43 proposed the Pythagorean fuzzy Maclaurin symmetric mean (MSM) operator and Pythagorean fuzzy weighted MSM operator. Gao et al 44 defined some novel Pythagorean fuzzy interaction aggregation operators in MADM. Wei and Lu 45 used power aggregation operators [46][47][48] to develop some Pythagorean fuzzy power aggregation operators. Liang et al 49 developed the Pythagorean fuzzy Bonferroni mean (PFBM) operator and weighted PFBM operator. Liang et al 50 developed the Pythagorean fuzzy geometric Bonferroni mean and weighted Pythagorean fuzzy geometric Bonferroni mean operators. Wei and Wei 51 presented some similarity measures between PFSs based on the cosine function and applied these similarity measures and weighted similarity measures between PFSs to pattern recognition and medical diagnosis. Garg 52 studied a novel accuracy function under interval-valued PFSs for solving the multicriteria decision-making problem.

The MSM operator was originally introduced by Maclaurin 53 and then developed by Detemple and Robertson. 54 The prominent characteristic of the MSM is that it can capture the interrelationship among the multi-input arguments. The MSM operator can provide more flexible and robust information fusion and make it more adequate to solve MADM in which the attributes are independent. Moreover, for a given collection of arguments, the MSM operator is monotonically decreasing with respect to the values of the parameter, which can reflect the risk preferences of the decision makers in practical situations. In the past few years, the MSM has received more and more attention, and many important results both in theory and application are developed. [55][56][57] In spite of this, on the basis of IFS and PFS, Yager 58 further proposed the q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets (q-ROFs) in which the sum of the qth power of the membership degree and the qth power of the degrees of nonmembership is restricted to 1, that is, ≤ μ ν + 1 q q

. We can find that the q-ROFs are more general because IFSs and PFSs are all their special cases. It is worth noting that as the rung increases, the space of acceptable orthopairs increases, and the more orthopairs satisfy the bounding constraint. So we can express a wider range of fuzzy information by using q-ROFs. Liu and Wang 59 proposed the q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted averaging (q-ROFWA) operator and the q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted geometric (q-ROFWG) operator to deal with the decision information. Liu and Liu 60 combined the BM operator with q-rung orthopair fuzzy numbers (q-ROFNs) to propose the q-rung orthopair fuzzy BM (q-ROFBM) operator, the q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted BM (q-ROFWBM) operator, the q-rung orthopair fuzzy geometric BM operator;, and the q-ROFWG BM operator; then the MAGDM methods are developed based on these operators. Wei et al 61 proposed the q-rung orthopair fuzzy generalized Heronian mean (q-ROFGHM) operator, q-rung orthopair fuzzy geometric Heronian mean (q-ROFGHM) operator, q-rung orthopair fuzzy generalized weighted Heronian mean operator, and q-ROFWG Heronian mean operator.

From the above analysis, we can see that most of the existing q-rung orthopair fuzzy aggregation operators are based on the algebraic product and algebraic sum of q-ROFs to carry the aggregation process that does not consider the interrelationship among the multi-input arguments. In recent years, many researchers studied the MSM operator and its applications that only consider the case that arguments take the form of crisp numbers. [62][63][64] To date, we have not seen any research based on MSM for information fusion under q-ROFs. Therefore, it is meaningful to pay attention to this issue. Motivated by this idea, we focus our attention to extend the MSM to aggregate the q-ROFNs and their application in MADM in this paper. To do so, the remainder of this paper is set out as follows. In Section 2, we introduce some basic concepts related to q-ROFs and some operational laws of q-ROFNs. In Section 3, we develop the q-rung orthopair fuzzy MSM (q-ROFMSM) operator and q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted MSM (q-ROFWMSM) operator. In Section 4, we develop the q-rung orthopair fuzzy dual MSM (q-ROFDMSM) operator and q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted dual MSM (q-ROFWDMSM) operator. In Section 5, we apply the q-ROFWMSM operator to develop the MADM model with q-ROFNs. In Section 6, a practical example is given to verify the developed approach and deliver the sensitivity analysis and comparative analysis. In Section 7, we conclude the paper and give some remarks.

Theorem 2 For given q-ROFNs a i n ˜( = 1,2,…, ) i and k n = 1,2,…, , the q-ROFMSM is monotonically decreasing with respect to the parameter k.
Proof On the basis of Theorem 1, we have
First, we prove that the function f k ( ) is monotonically decreasing with respect to the parameter k. On the basis of Lemmas 1 and 2, we have
Then, we take the following proof by the contradiction method. We suppose that f k ( ) is monotonically increasing with respect to the parameter k; then it follows that
Also, because
However, according to the elementary mean inequality, 47 we have

Clearly, it is in contradiction to the elementary mean inequality. Therefore, the function f k ( ) is monotonically decreasing with respect to the parameter k. Similarly, we can also prove that the function g k ( ) is monotonically increasing with respect to the parameter k. By using the score function of PFNs, we have

Because the function f k ( ) is monotonically decreasing with respect to the parameter k, so f k f k ( ( + 1) -( )) < 0; the function g k ( ) is monotonically increasing with respect to the parameter k, so we can imply g k g k ( ( ) -( + 1)) < 0. On the basis of the above result, we have

3.2 | The q-ROFWMSM operator

In Section 3.1, it can be seen that the q-ROFMSM operator does not consider the importance of the aggregated arguments. However, in many real practical situations, especially in MADM, the weights of attributes play an important role in the process of aggregation. To overcome the limitation of the q-ROFMSM operator, we shall propose the q-ROFWMSM operator as follows.

4 | THE q-ROFDMSM OPERATOR AND THE q-ROFWDMSM OPERATOR 4.1 | The q-ROFDMSM operator

In Section 4.1, it can be seen that the q-ROFDMSM operator does not consider the importance of the aggregated arguments. div.head: | MODEL FOR MADM WITH q-ROFNs
div.p: In this section, we shall use the q-ROFWMSM operator to MADM with q-ROFNs. Let
be a discrete set of alternatives and
be the set of attributes. Let ω ω ω ω = ( , ,…, )
be the weight vector of attributes, where
div.formula: ∈ ω [0, 1] j , j n = 1, 2,…, , and ∑ ω = 1 j n j =1 . Suppose that R r μ ν ˜= ( ˜) = ( , ) ij m n ij ij m n ×
div.p: × is the q-ROF decision matrix, where μ ij indicates the degree that the alternative A i satisfies the attribute G j given by the decision maker, ν ij indicates the degree that the alternative A i does not satisfy the attribute G j given by the decision maker,
In the following, we apply the q-ROFWMSM operator to MADM problems with q-ROFNs.
Step 1. We use the decision information given in matrix R ˜, and the q-ROFWMSM operator
to derive the overall preference values r i m ˜( = 1, 2,…, ) i of the alternative A i .

Step 2. Calculate the scores S r i m (˜) ( = 1, 2,…, ) i of the overall q-ROFNs r i m ˜( = 1, 2,…, ) i to rank all the alternatives A i m ( = 1, 2,…, ) i and then to select the best one(s) (if there is no difference between two scores S r (˜) i and S r ( ˜) j , then we need to calculate the accuracy degrees H r (˜) i and H r ( ˜) j of the collective overall preference values r ˜i and r ˜j, respectively, and then rank the alternatives A i and A j in accordance with the accuracy degrees H r (˜) i and H r ( ˜) j ). In this section, we shall present a numerical example to show the potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization with q-ROFNs to illustrate the method proposed in this paper. There is a panel with five possible emerging technology enterprises A i ( = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) i to select. The experts select four attributes to evaluate the five possible emerging technology enterprises: (1) G 1 is the technical advancement; (2) G 2 is the potential market and market risk; (3) G 3 is the industrialization infrastructure, human resources, and financial conditions; (4) G 4 is the employment creation and the development of science and technology. The five possible emerging technology enterprises A i ( = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) i are to be evaluated using the q-ROFNs by the decision maker under the above four attributes (whose weighting vector ω = (0.2, 0.1, 0.3, 0.4) T ), as listed in the following matrix.
In the following, we use the approach developed to show the potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization of five possible emerging technology enterprises.

Step 1. We use the decision information given in matrix R ˜, and the q-ROFWMSM operator to obtain the values r ˜i of the emerging technology enterprises A i ( = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) Step 3. Rank all the emerging technology enterprises A i ( = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) i in accordance with the scoresS r i (˜) ( = 1, 2, …, 5)
div.formula: i : ≻ ≻ ≻ ≻ A A A A A 5 3 24
div.p: 1 , and thus the most desirable emerging technology enterprise is A 5 .

div.head: | The influence of the parameters k on decision-making result
div.p: To reflect the influence with the different value of the parameter k, we use a different parameter k in our proposed method to rank the alternatives. The ranking results are shown in Table 1 (when q = 3).

From Table 1, we can see that with the parameter k change according to the decision maker's subjective preferences; the ranking results are slightly different, which indicates that the q-ROFWMSM operator can reflect the decision maker's risk preferences. Moreover, by further analysis, it is noted that the score values obtained by the q-ROFWMSM operator became smaller as the parameter k increases for the same alternative. In real practical decision-making situations, decision makers can choose the appropriate value in accordance with their risk preferences. In general, we take k = [n/2] for computation in practical problems, where the symbol [] means round function and n is the number of attributes, which is not only intuitive and simple, but also in this case, the risk preferences of the decision maker are neutral and the interrelationship of the individual arguments can be fully taken into account.
T A B L E 1 Score values obtained by the q-ROFWMSM and the rankings of alternatives Abbreviation: q-ROFWMSM, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted Maclaurin symmetric mean.
6.3 | The influence of the parameters q on the decision-making result

In the following, we will discuss the influence of the parameter q on the decision-making result based on the q-ROFWMSM operator, and the ranking results with the different values q are shown in Table 2 (when k = 2).

From Table 2, we know that the ranking results may be different for the different parameters q by the q-ROFWMSM operator. However, the best alternative is A 5 . The decision makers can choose the appropriate parameter value q by their preferences. Furthermore, from Table 2, we can easily know that the score functions based on the q-ROFWMSM operator became smaller and smaller.

div.head: | Comparative analysis
div.p: In what follows, we compare our proposed method with other existing methods including the q-ROFWA operator and q-ROFWG operator proposed by Liu and Wang 59 as follows:
Definition 10 59 Let a μ ν j n ˜= ( , )( = 1, 2,…, ) j j j be a collection of q-ROFNs,
div.formula: ω ω ω ω = ( , ,…, ) n T 1 2
div.p: be the weight vector of a j n ˜( = 1, 2,…, ) j , and ω > 0 (50) By using the decision information given in matrix R ˜, and the q-ROFWA and q-ROFWG operators, the aggregating results are shown in Table 3.
div.formula: j , ∑ ω = 1 j n j =1 .Then ⎛ ⎝ ⎜ ⎜ ⎞ ⎠ ⎟ ⎟ ∏ ∏ q a a a μ ν -ROFWA ( ˜, ˜, …, ˜) = 1 - ( 1 -( ) ) , ( ) ω n j n j q ω j n j ω 1 2 =1 =1 j q j (49
div.p: According to the aggregating results shown in Table 3, the score functions of the emerging technology enterprises are shown in Table 4.

According to the score functions shown in Table 4 and the comparison formula of score functions, the ordering of the emerging technology enterprises is shown in Table 5. Note that "﹥" means "preferred to." As we can see, depending on the aggregation operators used, the Abbreviation: q-ROFWMSM, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted Maclaurin symmetric mean.
ordering of the emerging technology enterprises is the same and the best emerging technology enterprises is A 5 .

From the above analysis, it can be seen that two methods have the same best-emerging technology enterprise A 5 , and two methods' ranking results are slightly different. This verifies that the method we proposed in this paper is reasonable and effective.

(1) Compared with the methods proposed by Liu and Wang, 59 the q-ROFWMSM operator we proposed has a desirable property that it monotonically decreases with respect to the parameter k, which enables the decision makers to choose the appropriate value in accordance with their risk preferences. If the decision maker prefers risk, we can take the parameter as large as possible; if the decision maker averts risk, we can take the parameter as small as possible. Furthermore, the models proposed by Liu and Wang 59 do not have this property of parameter so it is difficult to determine the parameters to reflect the decision maker's attitude in real practical decision making. (2) Compared with the methods proposed by Liu and Wang, 59 the main advantage of our method is that it can deal with interrelationship among the multi-input arguments, whereas the two methods proposed by Liu and Wang 59 did not consider interrelationship Abbreviations: q-ROWFA, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted averaging; q-ROFWG, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted geometric.

T A B L E 3 The aggregating results of the emerging technology enterprises by the q-ROFWA (q-ROFWG) operators q-ROFWA q-ROFWG A 1 (0.5474, 0.4730) (0.5217, 0.5020) Abbreviations: q-ROWFA, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted averaging; q-ROFWG,q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted geometric.

div.head: T A B L E 4
div.p: The score functions of the emerging technology enterprises q-ROFWA q-ROFWG Abbreviations: q-ROWFA, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted averaging; q-ROFWG, q-rung orthopair fuzzy weighted geometric.

among the multi-input arguments. Therefore, our method is more general. Moreover, the methods proposed by Liu and Wang 59 do not have the ability to dynamically adjust to the parameter according to the decision maker's risk attitude, so it is difficult to solve the risk MADM in real practice. Our method can overcome the drawbacks of the methods proposed by Liu and Wang, 59 because the q-ROFWMSM operator can provide more flexible and robust information fusion and make it more adequate to solve MADM in which the attributes are independent. According to the comparisons and analysis above, the q-ROFWMSM operator we proposed is better than the other methods proposed by Liu and Wang 59 for aggregating the q-ROFNs. Therefore, the q-ROFWMSM is more suitable to solve MADM with q-ROFNs.

div.head: | CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, we investigate the MADM problem with q-ROFNs. Then, motivated by the idea of MSM operator and dual MSM operator, we extend the MSM operator and dual MSM operator to q-ROFNs to propose the q-ROFMSM operator, q-ROFDMSM operator, q-ROFWMSM operator, and q-ROFWDMSM operator. Some desirable properties and special cases of these operators are discussed in detail. Then, we have used the q-ROFWMSM operator to develop an approach to solve the q-ROF MADM problems. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the feasibility of the proposed methods and deliver the sensitivity analysis and comparative analysis. In a future study, we shall extend the MSM operator to decision making, [67][68][69][70][71][72] risk analysis, and other fuzzy environments. [73][74][75][76][77][78][79][80][81][82][83][84][85][86]
